interlinear-text.item: GSK Os de bovins et de caprins [3]

phrase.item: The Bride Bone
At the top of the lower leg there is a small round bone covered in flesh, which we call “the bride bone.”
Whoever gets it [at a meal] gives that meat to someone else.
If that person knows that it's the bride bone, they don't take it; if they do take it they become indebted.
The conditions of the debt are like so: if they take [the bone] and swallow it with the meat, they have won.
If they are unable, they must always take it with them; no matter where the person who gave it to them asks that they give it back, they must have it on hand.
If the [first person] comes and [the loser] does not have it, they are obligated to give them anything [they ask for], but if they [can] give it back on the spot, they are no longer in debt.
Brother's Bone
Furthermore, there are the following bones: the humerus, the scapula, and the “brother's bone”(forearm bone: ulna and radius).
There is a lot of meat on the humerus.
When you eat it you can (it is possible to) break it.
But we do not break the “brother's bone;” only someone who neither the mother, nor the father, nor himself have brothers can break it.
If you have a brother or your mother or father have brothers, you mustn't break it or else one of the will die. In the Persian dialect of Wakhan, we call it “brother's bone.”
Scapula (shoulder blade)
We call the scapula the shoulder bone and, whether it is true or not, we say that he who takes it and gnaws the meat off it can look through it and see everything that is happening in the world.
Ossicle
The ossicle is the knee bone at the extremity of the leg. In Tadjik we call it “bedel.”
It is also an omen, or children play with it.
This game is called the ossicles. Everyone plays their own way;
The different sides of the ossicle are designated: king, vizier, thief, and peasant. We throw (roll like dice) them.
